title: 106_s1746
content:
The Act may be cited as the "United States-Turkey Free Trade Agreement Act of 1999". The Republic of Turkey has played a significant role in Europe, Asia, and the Middle East since its founding in 1923. The friendship between the United States and Turkey dates back to the late 18th century, with numerous treaties and agreements solidifying their relationship. Turkey has been a strategic partner of the United States since World War II, solidifying their alliance through various agreements. Turkey is strategically located between Europe and Asia, bordering the Black Sea and the Mediterranean Sea. It is also an important industrialized economy and has made significant progress in liberalizing its economy since the 1980s. Turkey has made significant progress in liberalizing its economy since the 1980s and has joined global trading systems like the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the World Trade Organization. Despite a strong friendship, the trading relationship between the United States and Turkey remains small. In 1998, US merchandise exports to Turkey were $3.5 billion, while imports from Turkey were less than 0.3 percent of total US imports. A free trade agreement between the two countries would benefit both by expanding their commercial ties. The United States aims to negotiate a Free Trade Agreement with Turkey to achieve more open, equitable, and reciprocal market access, as well as reduce barriers that hinder trade between the two countries. The President is authorized to enter into a trade agreement with Turkey, with tariff proclamation authority to modify duties as needed. No proclamation can reduce duty rates below 50% of the original rate. The Act prohibits reducing duty rates below 50% of the original rate, sets a minimum 10-year gap for duty reductions, and limits the overall reduction in duty rates under trade agreements. The Act prohibits duty rate reductions below 50% of the original rate, with a minimum 10-year gap between reductions. Staging exemptions are granted for articles not produced in the United States. The Commission advises the President on exempting articles from staging. The President can round annual reductions for simplicity. Duty rate changes require inclusion in an implementing bill. Bilateral agreements with Turkey aim to reduce and eliminate tariffs. The bilateral agreement between the United States and Turkey aims to reduce and eliminate tariffs and nontariff barriers to trade, leading to a free trade agreement between the two countries. Before entering into any trade agreement, the President must consult with Congress and relevant committees to discuss the nature and impact of the agreement. The implementation of the United States-Turkey Free Trade Agreement is also outlined. Before entering into a trade agreement, the President must notify Congress, submit required law changes, and provide the final legal text of the agreement along with implementing bill and proposed administrative actions. Before a trade agreement is finalized, the President must inform Congress, submit necessary legal changes, and provide the legal text, implementing bill, and proposed administrative actions. The supporting information required includes an explanation of how the agreement will impact existing laws and a statement on the progress made towards the objectives of the Act. The implementing bill for a trade agreement must meet specific criteria outlined in the Trade Act of 1974, including provisions that approve the agreement, necessary implementation measures, and compliance requirements. The President must provide Congress with information on how the agreement impacts existing laws and progress towards the Act's objectives before finalizing the agreement. The implementing bill for a trade agreement must meet specific criteria outlined in the Trade Act of 1974, including provisions for approval, implementation measures, and compliance with the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. SEC. 7. CONSIDERATION OF IMPLEMENTING BILL.

When the President submits a bill to implement the trade agreement, it will be introduced and considered according to the Trade Act of 1974. Amendments to the Trade Act of 1974 will include references to the United States-Turkey Free Trade Agreement Act of 1999.
